summary: This is the U.S. Government's memorandum in support of pretrial detention for Ghislaine Maxwell, filed in the Southern District of New York. It argues she is an extreme flight risk due to the seriousness of the charges, strength of evidence, her international ties, multiple citizenships, substantial wealth, and lack of meaningful ties to the United States.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts and perjury, alleged to have partnered with Jeffrey Epstein to groom and abuse underage girls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as Maxwell's partner in a scheme to sexually abuse underage girls at his properties; financial transfers between his accounts and Maxwell's are noted.

persons.name: G Max
persons.context: Name under which Maxwell registered a new phone number while allegedly in hiding to avoid detection.

connections.description: Partners in a scheme to sexually exploit minors; Maxwell was one of Epstein's closest associates and played a key role in identifying, grooming, and abusing underage girls for him.
Between 2007 and 2011, approximately more than $20 million was transferred from accounts associated with Epstein to accounts associated with Maxwell, with millions subsequently transferred back.

events.title: Period of Alleged Abuse Scheme
events.description: Maxwell and Epstein allegedly conspired to sexually abuse underage girls at Epstein's properties in New York, Florida, and New Mexico.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition Testimony
events.description: Maxwell gave deposition testimony in a civil lawsuit in the SDNY, where she allegedly repeatedly lied under oath about her role in facilitating the abuse of minors.

events.title: Sale of NYC Residence
events.description: Maxwell sold a New York City residence for $15 million through an LLC, with over $14 million subsequently deposited into and transferred between her accounts.

events.title: Epstein Indictment Unsealed / Maxwell Goes into Hiding
events.description: After the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein was unsealed, Maxwell stopped appearing in public and began hiding in locations in New England, moving locations and changing contact information.

events.title: Purchase of New Hampshire Property
events.description: A 156-acre property in Bradford, New Hampshire, was acquired in an all-cash purchase through an anonymized LLC, where Maxwell was reportedly hiding.

events.title: Grand Jury Returns Indictment
events.description: A federal grand jury in the SDNY returned a sealed indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with multiple counts related to the sexual exploitation of minors and perjury.

keyFacts: The government alleges Ghislaine Maxwell, in partnership with Jeffrey Epstein, exploited and abused girls as young as 14 between approximately 1994 and 1997.
Maxwell is charged with conspiracy, enticing and transporting minors for illegal sex acts, and two counts of perjury for lying under oath in a 2016 civil deposition.

The government argues Maxwell is an extreme flight risk due to her citizenship in the U.S., U.K., and France; possession of three passports; access to millions of dollars across numerous bank accounts; and lack of meaningful ties to the U.S.
Financial records show transfers of over $20 million between Epstein and Maxwell's accounts from 2007-2011, and Maxwell received over $14 million from the 2016 sale of a NYC property.

After Epstein's indictment was unsealed in July 2019, Maxwell allegedly went into hiding, moving locations, changing her phone number (registered under 'G Max'), and was found on a recently purchased, secluded property in New Hampshire.
